column8: J. F.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|3||2547|The paper deals with an extensive series of shock-recovery experiments performed on both nonporous crystalline basalt and its granulated and sieved counterpart to study the role of porosity and grain size in shock motomorphic effects under otherwise identical conditions. Shocked samples are compared with unshocked starting material in terms of textural and mineralogical modifications attributable to shock. A comparative petrographic and chemical characterization is presented of pulverized and sieved lunar basalt 75035 shocked between 6 and 75 GPa in comparison with holocrystalline disks of the same basalts shocked in 10 earlier experiments. Specifically
column9: a petrographic classification of shock features is given
column10: along with an estimation of relative amounts of shock glasses and a chemical characterization of shock glasses in each shocked granular basalt.|

column1: 1977LPSC....8.1697S|1977|Shock metamorphism of lunar and terrestrial basalts.|Schaal
column4: F.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1697|Lonar Crater (India) basalt and lunar basalt 75035 were shock loaded under controlled laboratory conditions up to 1000 kbar
column5: generally in a CO/CO2 (1:1) environment evacuated to 10 to the minus seventh power torr. The Kieffer et al. (1976) classification scheme of progressive shock metamorphism is found to apply to lunar basalts. The major shock features of the five classes that span the range 0 to 1000 kbar are described. Only three out of 152 basalt specimens show shock effects in their natural state as severe as Class 2 features. The scarcity of shocked basalt hand samples in contrast to the abundance of shock-produced agglutinates and homogeneous glass spheres in the lunar regolith indicates the dominant role of micrometeorite impact in the evolution of the lunar regolith. The overall glass content in asteroidal and Mercurian regoliths is considered.|

column6: T. L.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1489|Three Apollo 17 basalts were studied by the laser Ar-39-Ar-40 method. The 70215 basalt has a normal well-behaved Ar-39-Ar-40 release pattern; the 70017 basalt has a disturbed release pattern which indicates a limited intermediate maximum age followed by a broad low-age region; and the 75035 basalt has a pattern initially similar to 70017 that is followed by a high-temperature maximum age. The laser study shows that all mineral systems in 70215 have small and uniform temperature losses
column7: while the laser-determined ages for 70017 and 75035 are
column9: primarily controlled by the minerals containing mesostasis inclusions. It is possible that the drop in ages observed by the conventional Ar-39-Ar-40 method was due not only to recoil of Ar-39 during neutron irradiation but also to gas loss from some minerals. It is suggested that the plagioclases are the best minerals to use for a reliable age.|

column8: J. H.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1473|Uranium
column10: and isotopic lead data for components of basalt 70017 are reported
column11: and it is found that the whole rock
column13: and ilmenite points in a concordia diagram plot along a chord intersecting the curve at 3.7 and 4.33 eons. The plagioclase data do not seem to lie on this line. The data for 70017 appear to plot along a distinctly different chord in a concordia diagram than do the data for 75055 and 75035
column14: two other Apollo 17 mare basalts. The lead data are in accord with Sm-Nd results. A 3.7 eon crystallization age for 70017 would be consistent with the same kind of parentless lead that is indicated by previous studies of soils and soil breccias from stations at Taurus-Littrow. The Th/U ratio in ilmenite is 2.2
column15: and the concentrations of these two elements are approximately twice those in pyroxene.|

column1: 1976LPSC....7..501K|1976|The long-term average of the galactic cosmic-ray iron group composition studied by the track method.|Krätschmer
column4: W.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||501|Samples of lunar rock 75035 and of the meteorite Patwar have been investigated to study the long-term average of the galactic cosmic-ray composition by track measurements on feldspar crystals. For ion identification
column5: the double-marking method has been applied to fossil cosmic-ray and Fe calibration tracks. The results obtained on the Patwar meteorite indicate that the 60-million-year average and the present-day cosmic-ray (Cr + Mn)/Fe abundance ratios are about equal. The lunar sample showed an enhanced abundance ratio
column6: which probably is the result of the complex burial history of the rock. Beside the compositional data
column7: information has been obtained on the degree of influence of annealing effects and on nuclear fragmentation parameters.|

column1: 1975LPSC....6.1509T|1975|The history of lunar bombardment inferred from <SUP>40</SUP>Ar-<SUP>39</SUP>Ar dating of highland rocks.|Turner
column4: P. H.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||1509|Ar-40-Ar-39 age determinations for some Apollo 16 and 17 highland rocks are reported
column5: and the chronology of lunar highland samples is discussed. While basalt 75035 is found to have an age of 3.77 b.y.
column6: the argon release patterns from two plagioclase separates of 75035 both show high-temperature increases in apparent age to 3.85 b.y.
column7: for unknown reasons. Two models of the chronology are examined. One model assumes that the ages are dominated by basin-forming events; the alternative model
column8: in which the chronology is dominated by cratering events of subbasin size
column9: may be used to determine cratering as a function of time close to 4.0 b.y. The association of the ages of the Apollo 17 massif rocks with the Serenitatis event restricts the basin chronology within very narrow limits

column1: 1975LPSC....6..773J|1975|X-ray diffraction and electron microscope studies of clinopyroxenes from lunar basalts 75935 and 75075.|Jagodzinski
column8: L.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||773|X-ray diffraction patterns of 35 clinopyroxene grains chosen at random from the rocks 75035 and 75075 are more or less rotated up to 40 deg approximately about b-axes. This rotation characteristic is much more pronounced in grains from rock 75035 than in those from rock 75075. The diffraction patterns indicate the exsolution of pigeonite and augite. There is only one exception: a pigeonite-free twinned augite. Electron microscopy of one of these grains revealed small areas with bent (100) planes.|

column5: N. Z.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||707|Rock 75035 is a medium-grained
column7: subophitic ilmenite basalt collected from the rim of Camelot Crater
column8: and is believed to represent the subfloor basalts of the Taurus-Littrow valley. The rock consists of the major minerals pyroxene (45%)
column10: and ilmenite (17%). Minor minerals include cristobalite (about 5%)
column16: and rare ulvospinel. No olivine or armalcolite was observed in the specimen 75035
column19: this rock is similar to others collected from Camelot and other stations during the Apollo 17 mission. These rocks are almost identical to the Type B ilmenite basalts of Mare Tranquillitatis.|
